Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2018 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC), currently celebrating its 34th year, is a top-tier academic security conference that averages about 250-300 highly skilled security professional and student attendees per year. ACSAC regularly brings together the foremost minds in academic, governmental and commercial computer security to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. In addition to the technical papers, the conference program will include keynotes by distinguished speakers, tutorials, case studies, panels, a poster session, and works-in-progress talks. This year's Hard Topic Theme is Big Data for Security. Attendees also have the opportunity to participate in affiliated workshops on various topics in security. This project provides travel support for 10-15 students and thus helps build the next generation of cybersecurity professionals by facilitating interaction of students with experts in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. ACSAC is a highly competitive, peer-reviewed conference. The conference program is comprised of two days of tutorials and workshops, and three days of keynote talks, panels, a "works-in-progress" or WIP session, a poster session, and technical paper sessions.

The ACSAC 2018 Student Support grant provided NSF funds for ACSAC 2018, which was held in San Juan, PR on December 3-7, 2018. The conference was also supported with supplemental DHS funds provided under an earlier ACSAC 2017 Student Support grant.

NSF and DHS funds supported students from U.S. educational institutions including recipients of Scholarships for Women Studying Information Security (SWSIS), which provides assistance to women studying for their Bachelors or Masters degrees in fields relating to information security. Separate ACSA funding supported students from foreign institutions. All other students attending the conference and/or pre-conference workshops or tutorials received discounted registration fees paid by ACSAC from general registration fees.

The attached table provides statistics on overall ACSAC 2018 attendance, technical papers, and supported students, including degrees pursued, active roles in the conference, women, and members of underrepresented groups.

ACSAC 2018 featured two keynote talks and supplemental DHS funding was used to support conference fees and travel costs for the keynote speakers: Distinguished Practitioner Keynote: Why Privacy Engineering Matters Now, Michelle Dennedy, Vice President and Chief Privacy Officer, Cisco; and Invited Keynote: AI in Cybersecurity: Applications, Open Problems, and Future Directions, Alina Oprea, Professor of Computer Science, Northeastern University.

A key goal of the ACSAC 2018 Student Support grant was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conferences gained valuable insight into current research. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting technical papers and a poster. Attendees learned from the students and made connections that could lead to future employment. The invited keynote speeches gave conference attendees leading experts? perspective on applying security to difficult technical problems. Similarly, the tutorials offered attendees a diverse set of classes in key topics areas.

ACSAC is committed to increasing the quality and quantity of members of underrepresented groups and women in cybersecurity education and ultimately the cybersecurity profession. In support of this commitment, ACSAC 2018 worked proactively to recruit members of underrepresented groups and women from HBCU's, national societies and associations, universities in Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, the GREPSEC series of workshops, and the SWSIS program. This resulted in supporting a number of members of underrepresented groups and women as well as students from local universities in Puerto Rico.

The ACSAC conference is widely publicized and open to all members of the international information security community. The conference proceedings were published by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and are available via the ACM Digital Library. The Proceedings were made freely available to all conference attendees electronically via the ACSAC website.

ACSAC greatly appreciates NSF and DHS support. The conference helps feed the development of new computer and network security technologies and their application to solve address critical security, resilience, and privacy challenges in today's information security systems. By promoting and supporting student participation, tutorial instructors, and keynote speakers, the conference facilitates education and interaction and helps develop and groom the next generation of security professionals.
